messages.message_text: Kyle   7:05 PM I got this message from a recruiter I know; not for me, but wanted to share here if anyone would like an intro: Looking for an Interim SEO Product Director for a 4-month project.  This is a remote opportunity with occasional travel to Dallas & San Francisco. Below are the qualifications for this position:  Identify, measure, and interpret current state of SEO across our brands to validate product strategy.  Provide research, analysis, and support for identifying, evaluating, and resolving strategic opportunities.  Develop and manage a road map based on the current state of the SEO, highlighting timing, impact and work required from key stakeholder engagement strategy on all initiatives.  Build relationships with key business partners and other brand stakeholders; articulates product needs clearly and succinctly to different audiences and cross-functional partners  executive level storytelling.  Has in-depth knowledge of industry trendsand standardsto introduce the continual process, tool, and methodology improvements.  Assist in managing Agency.  Experienced at bringing Sr. Leadership along the strategic road mapping journey.  Collaborate and lead in key initiatives of implementation.       Retail experience preferred! Company is confidential (lol recruiters) 30 hours a week $115/hr If anyone would like an intro, let me know in DM! 3 replies Last reply 3 months ago

Jason Wilson   3 months ago I will DM you. 1

messages.message_text: Ben Fisher   11:51 PM Why is it so hard to find a SEO person? We get a lot of replies, but no one can furnish a example audit.... BUT if you can please apply! https://wellfound.com/company/steady-demand/jobs/2617236-seo-specialist Wellfound (formerly AngelList Talent) SEO Specialist at Steady Demand  United States  Remote (Work from Home) Steady Demand is hiring a SEO Specialist in United States - Apply now on Wellfound (formerly AngelList Talent)! Steady Demand is a team of Google Business Profile and social media... +2 16 replies Last reply 2 months ago
replies: Ryan Cochrane   3 months ago Would you hire from Canada for this role?
Adam Di Frisco   3 months ago @Ben Fisher This is such a compelling job listing... I'll share with my network as well.
Boris Kuslitskiy (he/him)   3 months ago FYI, someone may not be able to quickly and independently produce a report without using the tools they usually use at work.

Boris Kuslitskiy (he/him)   3 months ago If you asked me to audit a site, I absolutely could, but it wouldn't be pretty and it wouldn't be nearly as fast as I'd do at work with the paid tools available there.
Ben Fisher   3 months ago Ryan, true story all our SEO team members are from Canada lol 1 4 1 1
Ben Fisher   3 months ago Thank you Adam
Ben Fisher   3 months ago Boris, what we usually get is an audit that is just a name cleansed version of one done prior
Boris Kuslitskiy (he/him)   3 months ago For people working in-house, a name cleansed version may as well be labeled and is private information.
Andrew Shotland   3 months ago Lol I think if you asked me for an audit I couldnt give you one as they are all covered by NDA 1 1
Ben Fisher   3 months ago But... they can be cleansed to not have details like client info

Adam Humphreys   3 months ago Its hard to relinquish technical audits because when I do it for a Fortune 200 energy company I cant share my findings with the general public even if the issues are readily available. (edited)

Alex Harford   2 months ago I've never had to provide an example prior audit to a company for an SEO role and would be wary of that. It's usually an interview plus sometimes a quick audit for one of their websites. I did a 5-6 hour audit when interviewing for one company - only a temporary and part-time role - I thought that was too much and wouldn't do it again. I got the job,  and they asked me for data from that audit (which I hadn't kept). (edited)
Adam Humphreys   2 months ago Ya Alex I tend to see it as people phishing for lists of how to do it.

Adam Di Frisco   2 months ago I don't see it as a problem honestly. I keep audits I've done all the time for examples of work. Cleaning them is really not that much work and I see it as a great way to stand out from competition. As far as the phishing goes, I've never thought of that but I guess I've never considered applying to an agency taht doesn't have a solid reputation.

Adam Humphreys   2 months ago Its more common than you think. Agencies I know also mentioned businesses posting requests for proposals, including audits of what they would do. So they get all this free work done, and SEO agencies fall for it.
Andrew Shotland   2 months ago I fell for this once from Rodan & Fields. Jerked me around for 6 months then tried to hire our tech SEO guy to do freelance on the cheap. 2

messages.message_text: Katherine Blake   10:24 PM Good afternoon all! My agency is looking for a freelance content specialist. Heres the posting: SEO Content Specialist (Freelance) Big Sea is looking for an experienced, vibrant and creative SEO Content Specialist to join our growing content team. Were seeking an outstanding SEO with a strong content creation background who can advise our clients on on-page, copy-based strategies to improve their organic reach. The skills were looking for include: Strong familiarity with SEO content best practices Experience in keyword research Familiarity with both content-led SEO and product-led SEO strategies A background in writing SEO optimized content (writing within this role will be minimal; however, youll be making recommendations to content creators) An understanding of internal linking strategy As part of this role, you will be expected to: Conduct content audits to determine opportunities for optimization on a website Produce monthly reports on traffic and keyword analytics Make on-page SEO recommendations for a variety of web content, including blogs, product and service pages, and landing pages Minor content production for significant text features (titles, headings, alt text, and meta descriptions) If interested, please send your resume and contact information to jobs@bigsea.co 3 6 replies Last reply 3 months ago

messages.message_text: Mike Blazer   1:28 AM I have a question. Don't know if this is the right channel to ask this... You're looking to hire an SEO to join your in-house SEO team, you're getting responses to your job posting, but many of the candidates are just kind of money-oriented. How do you identify candidates with sparkle in their eyes, highly motivated candidates who want to learn and grow professionally? What questions should I ask candidates to find the gems that may not have the expertise yet, but have the above attributes? +4 13 replies Last reply 2 months ago
replies: Jon Henshaw   2 months ago If they have sparkles in their eyes AND are highly motivated, then their likely curious and do their own stuff. So ask them about what they've done or are doing independently.

Mike Blazer   2 months ago I've hired people who had their own projects or side projects that they wanted to work on at the same time, even though their job with us was full time. One thing is if they have a hobby site that they spend time on weekends or whatever, and another thing is if they want to work on their stuff and still get paid by us by trying to look like they're working.

Jon Henshaw   2 months ago I have no doubt that those people were not providing you what you paid them to do. That said, if they are responsive, get their shit done, and are high performers, I don't think whether or not they're giving you 100% during the hours you tell them to work matters all that much. I do and produce plenty of stuff, but I make sure I do it on my time, or I make up that time for my employer on my own time. It's difficult to judge how someone is going to be, though. All I'm saying is that I wouldn't write them off because they may become your greatest asset. 4 1

Sophie Brannon   2 months ago Ask them questions about things that are up and coming or hot topics in the SEO industry (SGE for example or something similar) and if they have even a little bit of knowledge about it, then they likely have the motivation to push their learning and have some industry passion too. If they dont have any knowledge about it but you see them make a note about it to look into it later thats also a good green flag. You can also typically tell based on personality (avoid ego!) and what kind of questions they ask you about the business, what progression looks like and pushing for next steps at the end 1 1

Darren G   2 months ago Hi Mike, not sure what you mean by money-oriented, but wanting a fair pay doesn't make someone money-oriented. It's natural to seek a decent living. However, when interviewing, focus on their passion and curiosity about SEO. Ask about what they like about SEO and where they see it going and what drives them or how they keep up with trends. But remember, a quick learner who's eager to grow will also expect fair pay as they gain experience. It's about balancing passion with practical needs.

Mike Blazer   2 months ago Hello! The salary should be 100% decent and fair, nobody argues with that. But it seems like there are two types of people who respond to job posts: those who want to get the money and those who want to earn it. You know, the takers and the givers. And the ones who are just chasing the money are still telling you that they are givers as well. And I want to identify the givers before I hire them. I want a full-time employee to do the best job he or she can, not someone who is just faking the work process.

Darren G   2 months ago Hi Mike, totally get where you're coming from. It's all about finding the "givers" who are genuinely invested in their work. Maybe try asking about specific examples where they've gone above and beyond in previous roles. A trial period could also give you a real sense of their work ethic. It's a tough balance, but those genuine candidates with passion often shine through in the details and enthusiasm. Hope this helps! 1

Natan Gesher   2 months ago Have you considered adding a line at the bottom of the job description that says something like, "Please do not apply if you are money-oriented"? You could maybe try that for a week or two, and then compare the pool of definitely-not-money-oriented applicants against the pool of mixed money- and not-money-oriented applicants, to see which is better.
Mike Blazer   2 months ago I'm not getting 10k of applicants to make A/B tests
Adam Humphreys   2 months ago Look at their social media and what theyre sharing/following.

Sam Pennington   2 months ago Might sound silly but isn't this what probationary periods are for? Time to assess if the person is right for the role but professionally and personally. If you get the onboarding right, give them a decent level of work to do for the role and access output and quality it should tell you all you need to know. If your wondering how to get to selecting someone in the first place then that's about reading and understanding a CV. Roles, companies worked for, length of time in recent roles, reason for leaving etc.

Mika Lepist   2 months ago A bit late to the party, but here's my take as someone who is self employed but would prefer to be a part of a larger team: Lots of jobs ask for way too many things from SEOs. They're unrealistic. If that's the case, I think you're going to get lower quality applicants. If someone is highly motivated, the pay structure and environment should cater to that. I think one mistake people make are wanting go-getters and entrepreneurial types, but not providing an environment that is right for that mindset. I think you can easily tell who is motivated if they are interested in a role where there is substantial performance compensation but it also has to offer the ability to actually perform (no hurdles) (edited)

Nicolai at Yak Media   2 months ago I dont think that asking questions to find gems will help. These days candidates are so well-versed and trained to answer any kind of questions. During my hiring days I was always asking to show me their SEO in action. I was looking for stuff outside their 9to5 responsibilities, like work on their own sites, help on friends sites, etc. Hope its helpful.

messages.message_text: Shawn Rubel   9:05 PM Hi folks, Im looking to hire a consultant to help me understand the WHY about the following data Im seeing:  SemRush reports that our US traffic is declining and US traffic is increasing from our competitor. GSC reports that our US traffic has been flat over the last 12 months. I would like to know the specific terms where we are loosing traffic and marketshare in the US to our competitor. I would like to know the specific terms where our competitor is gaining marketshare (and we are missing the boat). If you can help me with this, please send me a DM to discuss in more detail. Thank you! 3 replies Last reply 2 months ago
replies: Kyle   2 months ago IIRC, SEMRush estimates traffic by position. This does not always accurately or directionally align with reality, unfortunately.
Crystal Ortiz   2 months ago DMd you

Graham  Maonaigh   2 months ago If you ignore SEMrush for a moment. Just look at GSC data as this is actual data from your Google presence. Firstly over that same period. Have your positions for search terms also remained somewhat static on aggregate. If so, have the numbers of impressions increased or decreased for the terms you rank for? If you are seeing impressions growing and your clicks remaining static you can assume two directions.  Heterogeneity factors are market growth/decline Homogeneous factors are related to changing behaviours or competitive forces you are facing. Its likely a mix of both

messages.message_text: Kavi Kardos   10:40 PM Hi everyone! Super excited to share that we're hiring for two positions at Uproer! We're a boutique agency in Minneapolis, MN with a team that is passionate about succeeding in search. We do SEO and SEM only, and we're performance-focused. We get results and are looking for two folks to join our team. We have an awesome culture that focuses on working to live, not living to work. We have a 32-hour work week, and we're just people looking to help people. These two roles aim to replace two people who are sadly leaving us to pursue opportunities that are outside the realm of search marketing. Fully remote within the US, and did I mention the 32-hour work week?! We're hiring for: A senior SEO analyst - someone who loves search and is ready to dig right into the thick of it - tactical experience and client management experience wanted, but happy to talk to anyone! Looking for 2-5 years experience. A content specialist - an organized individual that is eager to learn about how content impacts search, and how we can improve content strategies across SEO and SEM. This role is mostly focused on getting content through the production process and making sure it works with our clients. All experience welcome! Reach out to me for more deets or apply on LinkedIn. Sr. SEO Analyst: https://www.linkedin.com/jobs/view/3719612379/ Content Specialist: https://www.linkedin.com/jobs/view/3719607813/ (edited)  Uproer Uproer | Search Marketing Agency for SaaS & Ecommerce Where great companies go to get found. messages.message_text: Katie High   7:42 PM I have a client with a very specific need. I am looking for an SEO agency with substantial eCommerce experience- but particularly in high volume products (as in millions of parts) with complex selling/distribution channels. Does such a speciality exist? 7 replies Last reply 1 month ago
replies: Jonas Sickler   1 month ago Hi Katie. I have a few questions that could help folks make better recommendations for an agency: What industry is the client in (YMYL spaces, for example, would require specific expertise from an agency) Do they sell high consideration products that might benefit from a blog or knowledge base? Are they looking for a short-term contract for technical recs, or a long-term partnership? Are they also looking for UX/CRO work to augment traditional SEO performance? Some agencies are great with just ecom, but arent set up for high volume blog publication. Some might have a ton of experience in SaaS, but not as much in retail. More importantly, large brands often have strict regulatory or legal needs for data security and compliance, so these are also a consideration. (edited)

Katie High   1 month ago Hi Jonas, all great questions. Thank you. This client is in manufacturing- very parts focused. Some B2B but B2C as well. Mix of custom and stock. Just looking for SEO specifically- paid, UX, CRO handled elsewhere. Oh and likely long term. (edited)  1

Jonas Sickler   1 month ago Thanks Katie. Interesting. I had a feeling thats what it might be when you said the sales process was complex with millions of units moved. Ill check in with some folks I know to see if theres a good fit 1
